Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Effects of the Mississippi River plume on the spread of the Deepwater Horizon oil slick
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predicting the migration of the oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico is crucial for protecting sensitive wetlands and coastal fisheries from contamination. Ocean and shelf models make daily forecasts of landfall of the surface slick that are invaluable for coastal managers, however there have been several events of anomalous surface slick migration that were not forecast. Recent analysis indicates that discharge from the Mississippi River pushes oil offshore by deforming the sea surface height (SSH). This study proposes to describe pressure-driven flows of the buoyant oil slick using a two-layer, 2D Bernoulli model with friction. Combined with satellite data of SSH, sea surface temperature (SST) and ocean currents, and daily river discharge and weather data, this research will quantify the plume effect on oil slick dynamics. This modeling approach is simple and generalizable, and therefore could be adopted for other oil spills.

The ongoing oil spill resulting from the Deepwater Horizon explosion is the worst environmental disaster in US history. The location of the spill is such that, under some conditions, the Mississippi River plume can exert a strong control. This model will provide a simple, quantitative estimate of this plume effect on oil slick dynamics each day using daily satellite data; if significant, this effect of sea-surface height could easily be incorporated into more complex daily ocean/shelf model forecasts. Quantifying the plume effect will provide the science needed to determine whether strategic river diversions are effective for preventing landfall of oil slick in sensitive Louisiana wetlands. The model could also project longer-term changes in the plume effect resulting from anticipated seasonal changes in river stage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Millions of barrels of oil escaped into the Gulf of Mexico after the 20 April, 2010 explosion of Deepwater Horizon . Ocean circulation models were used to forecast the daily movement of the oil slick in the Gulf, however these numerical models were unsuccessful in predicting where oil would make landfall each day. Such prediction is necessary to allocate limited resources in order to protect human and ecological communities.

We discovered that the Mississippi River itself actually "pushed" oil from the Deepwater Horizon leak away from the coast, under conditions of high river flow and a calm ocean. This was caused by the formation of a freshwater mound around the Mississippi Delta, in which river water piled up to create a sea surface profile that sloped downward away from the Delta. The buoyant oil slid down this surface, somewhat like a ball on a tilting plate. We quantified this effect using satellite altimetry data to measure sea surface height, and sea surface temperature and image data from satellites to track the motion of river water and the surface oil slick.

To better understand the controls of the Mississippi River on movement of the Deepwater Horizon oil slick, and to generalize these results to be useful for future oil spills, we built a mathematical model to describe the relevant forces at work. By modeling the flow as a classic "oil and water" problem, in which the less dense oil sits atop the more dense sea water without mixing, we were able to describe the general motion of the oil slick in response to the tilting water surface created by the River. These results will be incorporated into more complex computer models of the Gulf of Mexico, to enable better prediction in future oil spills. More generally, the important effect of the freshwater mound that was identified by this study will help to better understand how river water, nutrients and sediment are mixed into the ocean - which is important for the ecology and fisheries of the Delta.
